awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Radiotherapy Planning for Organ Motion Management
awd_abstract_narration:
Radiotherapy is one of the most effective and commonly used modalities for cancer treatment. Radiotherapy uses high-energy radiation to eradicate cancer cells while sparing the surrounding normal tissue as much as possible. However, if unaccounted for, internal organ motion during radiation delivery may lead to underdosing of cancer cells or overdosing of normal tissue. Organ motion is of particular concern in the treatment of lung and abdominal cancers, where breathing induces large tumor displacement and organ deformation. A recent technological innovation is a new generation of radiotherapy systems equipped with on-board magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) scanners providing a real-time high-contrast movie of the patient's anatomy during radiation delivery. This research will develop the methods to enable use of real-time imaging to control the progress of radiation delivery in order to correct for any dose discrepancy, thus allowing treatment plans to actively adjust to anatomical changes.  If successful, the research will provide clinicians with real-time organ-motion management tools that have the potential to improve the delivery efficiency and radiation dose conformity for MRI-guided radiotherapy, leading to higher rates of disease control and fewer side effects for cancer patients, thus improving their quality of life after treatment.  The project will provide support for a graduate student who will benefit from the multi-disciplinary research environment.

This research employs medical-image processing techniques to infer the time-dependent state of the patient's anatomy from the stream of MRI sequences and to estimate the cumulative delivered dose in real-time. Using the inferred anatomical information, a stochastic model will be developed to project the immediate future trajectory of the anatomical motion. The cumulative dose estimation and the projected anatomical trajectory will be integrated as feedback and feed-forward control signals, respectively, into a stochastic control problem, which will be solved dynamically to (re)optimize the radiotherapy plan over the remainder of the treatment session. The control approach will be tested on clinical cancer patients previously treated with MRI-guided radiotherapy at a collaborating cancer center to quantify the anticipated improvement in plan quality and delivery efficiency. The project also provides a foundation from which to quantify the value of real-time MRI information.

por.por_cntn:
Organ motion poses a great challenge in the radiation treatment of lung and abdominal cancers. Traditionally, two main strategies have been used in the clinic to mitigate the impact of organ motion during radiation delivery. In the first approach, the target volume is expanded to ensure an adequate coverage of the tumor region irrespective of the exact location of the tumor. However, this approach exposes healthy normal tissue to large radiation dose levels potentially leading to normal-tissue toxicity. In the second approach, the tumor motion is tracked during radiation delivery and the radiation beam is turned off every time the tumor displacement is beyond a pre-specified boundary and the treatment is resumed once the tumor is within the boundary again. However, this approach prolongs the treatment time due to frequent beam interruptions, thereby causing patient inconvenience and decreasing operational throughput.

The objective of this project was to develop a new motion management approach to minimize treatment interruptions without the need to expand the target volume. The project consisted of three parts. The first part focused on developing new methods to predict the future trajectory of the organ motion during radiation delivery. The second part involved the development of dose estimation tools to calculate the dose accumulated in different parts of the anatomy in real time. Finally, the last part focused on the development of computational tools to automatically update the radiotherapy treatment plan over the remainder of the treatment session considering the latest information about the organ-motion trajectory and the cumulative dose deposited so far. Therefore, the radiotherapy treatment plan is dynamically adjusted to ensure the delivery of the planned dose in the presence of organ motion.  

Using deidentified data from previously treated cancer cases, we conducted computational experiments to test the performance of the tools developed as part of the project. Additionally, we ran computer simulation studies to compare the performance of the proposed motion management approach against traditional approaches. The results show that the new motion management approach has the potential to shorten the duration of each treatment session without compromising the quality of the delivered radiation dose with respect to the target coverage and normal-tissue sparing for cancer patients. Hence, if deployed clinically, the new motion management approach may improve patient experience and operational throughput, thereby increasing treatment availability. The benefit is potentially high as more than 50% of all cancer patients receive radiotherapy as part of their treatment.

The project was a collaborative effort in which the research team from Wichita State University worked closely with clinical collaborators from two cancer cancers. The project formed the foundation of a doctoral dissertation providing the Ph.D. student involved with the opportunity to work in a multidisciplinary research environment. It also led to training opportunities for undergraduate students. The project results were disseminated as journal articles and conference presentations to research communities. Also, outreach efforts were made to engage the broader public via presenting the project at local and state forums.
